text:
Looking for advice on getting from one city to another. This is our draft itinerary of the middle part of our trip:


Pompei to Matera - we are considering a bus (tour Pompei in the morning then there is one bus about 3:40pm )
Matera to Bari - Spend a couple of nights in Matera then we are considering a bus to Bari (1 hour bus ride)
Bari to Tropea - Spend a couple of nights in Bari, then we are considering renting a car ( the closest drop off seems to be the airport an hour train ride away. so 3.5 hour drive, then 1 hour train ride)
Tropea to Reggio Calabria - Couple of nights in Tropea then we are considering taking a train. (Trenitalia 1.5-2 hour ride)
Reggio Calabria to Siricusa - One night in RC then ferry to Messina, then train to Siracusa (3 hour train ride, Trenitalia)
Siracusa to Cefalu - Couple of nights in Siracusa then considering train (5+hours Trenitalia) or hiring driver (drive is about 3 hours) or rent a car.
Cefalu to Palermo - Few nights in Cefalu then train to Palermo
Part of the reluctance to just rent a car for this entire segment is that it seems hard to drive in the cities, hard to park in the cities, reluctant to drive through mountains, and pick up/drop off does not seem convenient in some areas.


How are the roads driving through the mountains from Siracusa to Cefalu? from Bari to Tropea? From Pompei to Matera?
Would the cost of hiring a driver compare to the cost of renting a car?
Any bus companies better than others, companies to avoid?
We are open to switching the order around somewhat.

comments.comment_text:
Hiring a driver will be much more expensive.
All the places you are going aren’t too difficult to drive in, a part from Bari and Palermo maybe. Just ask the places you are sleeping in to help you with the parking, when you arrive there you can move by bus in the city but you’ll be able to visit the surroundings by car. By car you’ll be able to see much more, do some beautiful detours and stop in every little village you’ll like: you’ll enjoy the countryside and the stunning places you will be visiting.
I think one night in Matera will be enough to see all there is to see, unless you want to have a relaxing break or visit the surroundings.
I’d add a night in Bari and maybe switch it with somewhere slightly more south like Ostuni to enjoy other places in Puglia (Ostuni, Lecce, Otranto are stunning) and not have to drive too much.

text: I am a novice and looking to book our 1st overseas trip. Approx 3 weeks. I was thinking of possibly doing a 15day coach tour covering Paris,Rome,Florence,Venice,Amsterdam, London and Swiss Alps.. then a week in italy at a destination of our choosing. There are deals through flight centre Australia. We are mid 40s are we too young for the coach tours? Any advice given would be greatly appreciated.

comments.comment_text: Not too young but so many cities in so few days seems like the getting to and from will take away a lot. Better to concentrate on no more than 3 cities as your base and maybe day trips from there. But these cities have so much to offer, even my living 2 months or more in many of them was only enough for a surface view!

Not too young. Currently on a coach tour in Slovenia. Half are retired, hubby and I in our fifties, our son in his twenties, a couple mid thirties, and the rest forties. I believe the average age of coach tours is fifties. It is our first European trip and loving it - go for it. But perhaps narrow it down to one country in 15 days, at the most two - the number of places that tour is going to is too much.
We also decided no way would we drive on the other side of the road, so coach trip seemed the best option.
A cruise is always another option, to see a few countries, but also that you can unpack your bag, for the length of the cruise.

In 15 days? No, to have a flavor of every place you have mentioned you would need at least 4/5 days each..pick the cities you really want to see.And use low cost flights if visiting different countries.

The 7 places you referenced in 15 days???? Sure, you'll get those photos of you all in front of the iconic backdrops before you rush off to the next photo shoot so you can post that to you FB page, but you won't be experiencing any of the richness and culture of any of those places. You're treating Europe like it's a theme park and you have to go on all the rides.

Eliminate about half those and for those that are left enjoy the things about them that can't be photographed.
Trip a Deal I have heard are great. Sometimes have 2 for price of 1. Have travelled with Trafalgar and can recommend. Then you can perhaps choose a place to spend time.

For your first overseas trip, cut it down to only a few countries. You will get to enjoy and relax as well. I can totally understand you wanting to do as much as possible especially as this is your first trip, but it may be a bit overwhelming. I've been traveling ever since I was born, and I love it, but it may well be too much for you guys. Whatever you do, enjoy!
Unless all you want to see is the inside of a bus or train, 5 countries in 15 days is madness
Our rule of thumb is 3 days in each city. You want to not just see the must sees but feel the culture of the city/country.

Personally I would skip the Coach tour. I've always planned my own trips and enjoy figuring out the logistics. Public transportation in Europe is incredible, and I would take a train over bus any day. Flights within Europe are often inexpensive too. London to Paris or Amsterdam flight could end up being the fastest and cheapest option. I'd start with a map (real or digital) put some pins where you want to go and start connecting dots and figure out a few routes, then start allotting days and see what you come up with. You might decide it's too ambitious and remove stops, or you might see that another place is on the way and add it.

That sounds like a great trip. No, you're definitely not too young. My 21 year old daughter & I have just been on a 12 day Trafalgar tour of Italy and I was worried that my daughter would feel left out, but no. There were about 6 others on the tour around her age and even 2 young kids with their parents.

I’ve been in 3 organised tours with Insight. They seem to have 40+ age on their tours and their coaches have a lot of legroom so for tall people (me) it was great. I found the tours called ‘Country Roads’ are slower paced with 2-3nights spent in each place and more free time. I loved the Northern Italy and France tours. Add on extra days at the starting and ending points to allow you to do more exploring ❤️🇮🇹🇫🇷🇦🇺

The best way to see a lot of Europe in little time is through an organized tour. Then just go back to the ones you really enjoyed. I did it when I was 21 and met people my age and some younger. I had a great time.

If the coach tour ticks your boxes in terms of cities and sightseeing - they provide a wonderful overview, your luggage is taken care of, you have a guide, you get easy access to all major sites. However you are often stuck eating at “tourist traps” and hotel buffets. Sometimes hotels are out of town - so check that too. I think a combination of the two as you have suggested is great.

Also from Australia and as part of a 5week trip to Europe we toured some of Italy with Insight. Our tour had 2 nights in each city apart from 1 night in Assisi. The pace can be quite hectic but we chose to stand down from most of the optional tours so we could investigate a city on our own. Think our tour was 14 days, so to cram all those countries into 15 days, I think most of the sites would be drive by, not a tour. Loved our tour director, driver and our luggage was taken care of.

We’ve just done 9 days in Croatia which we organised ourselves and we are about to start a two week tour through Italy with GAventures. It’s a small group tour with varying ages. We’re early 50’s which is the older end of the spectrum. I picked this tour as there is plenty of free time and you organise your own sightseeing at each location so I’ve organised visits to museums, an e-bike ride from Lucca to Pisa, visit to the Vatican etc. We stay approximately 2-3 days in each location. I wanted a tour that would take the hassle out of the travel arrangements and to meet some like minded travellers but without being on a very rigid schedule.
Also, as a fellow Australian I’ve had very mixed experiences with Flight Centre. Make sure that they select your seats for all of your flights at the time you book. Something our Flight Centre agent did not do. You end up with the worst seats in the middle back and with flights taking 14+ hours, followed by another 7hrs it’s matters where you sit!!
Just book a return flight to Rome. Then do Rome, Florence, Tuscany, maybe Puglia. Public transport is great and a coach tour is boring.
Far better off doing a cruise, unpack once and wake up in a new port nearly every day with the whole day to explore

I've been doing bus tours since my early 20's. Definitely good to do for your first overseas trip as everything is included and usually there are no line-ups to get into places and you also make good friendships with your coach mates. Trafalgar, Cosmos and Insight are all great. Perhaps do a tour of Italy (smaller mileage to cover) and then have a week of your own travel once you get your bearings. 15 days to cover all those km's throughout Europe means you'll be on a bus most of the day. Italy is relatively small and each great destination is only a few hours away so you will have way more time to explore and experience. If you are contemplating the south of Italy, I can help you with that. (The south is very different to the north.)

I've travelled both independently and on coach tours. You can gain a lot of information from the tour leaders and it takes the hassle out of getting from point A to point B, but my main complaint is that they insist on dropping you for hours in the middle of nowhere to shop. I travel to see the country, not to shop. They should offer an alternative for those not interested in retail therapy

Have a look at Expat tours online, we are in our 50’s from NZ and are currently on our 6th tour with them, this time to the Balkans. They cater for all ages and give you opportunities to explore independently instead of being led around like a sheep! 😊
I'm 68 and too young for coach crap....live a little.

I am from New Zealand and my husband and I booked everything ourselves - didn't go through a travel agent. We are doing "Planes, trains, and automobiles" and the odd ferry. going to France, Italy, Greece, Scotland and England. It is so easy to do and you get to do exactly what you want to. 15 days is not enough time to go to all of those places, you won't even "scratch the surface". Especially with the price of the flights to and from Europe.

Go the river/coastal route to avoid mountains.
As Treebeard said, always liked heading south...always seemed like going downhill !

We drive most summers in Europe and have seen a few caravans from the UK in Italy. We also see many from the Netherlands, Germany and France in Italy too as there are many great camping sites in and around the Lakes area in northern Italy.
There are probably a few ways to go avoiding the hills, down towards southern France then into Italy though if you wanted to go through Switzerland ( it's truly stunning) then there are plenty of tunnels that go through the Alps rather than facing some of the tighter alpine passes 😁

Tolls are higher if you go south through France, we use the tunnel, and go Belgium, Luxembourg (cheapest diesel en route), back into France, and then Switzerland. You need a vignette for Switzerland, (which covers you for the whole year) and then into Italy where you will pay tolls to get anywhere. (Car from Palma to Napoli was approx €50). I would avoid the tunnel on a Friday or Saturday though, plan for mid-week and/or early morning as the queue can be 10km+ with a 2 hour wait. Via Michelin is a good site to give you an idea of fuel and toll costs.

A few days ago, I read a debate about tipping or not. I am Italian and I can tell you how things are in many restaurant settings.

First of all, tips are often divided among the entire staff. Many waiters and chefs are seasonal workers, so they work for 4-6 months. Hourly wages in certain places can be as low as 3-4 euros! Not everyone, but really many are underpaid and exploited 7 days a week. Therefore, in my opinion, if the service is friendly and the food is good, leave a tip!

The taxi situation is quite different. Their salary is good. While not all taxis are the same, in Italy they are notorious for taking advantage of tourists who are unfamiliar with the routes, thus significantly increasing the fare. They are also known for refusing to accept card payments and insisting on cash in order to evade taxes.

It is advisable to search on YouTube for any video related to "taxi fare scams in Rome" to get a better understanding of the issue. These videos can provide real-life examples of tourists being overcharged or deceived by taxi drivers.
So be very careful if you decide to leave a tip.

Enjoy your travel! 😊

text:
Few tips for those who travel by train in Italy.

Buy tickets in advance so you can get cheaper rates through Trenitalia or Italo apps and websites.

You only need to VALIDATE paper tickets for regional/local trains (TRENO REGIONALE) before you board your train; paper tickets for INTERCITY, FRECCIABIANCA, FRECCIAARGENTO, FRECCIAROSSA and ITALO do not need to be validated cause they serve as reservations (they have date/time stamp and seat assigned). Forgetting to validate will get you fined. Validating machines are found all over the platforms.

Tickets both physical or digital may have to be scanned prior to accessing the platforms or they may be checked by station personnel at the access points leading to the platforms.

Carefully check train number and not the train type or destination on the station display to know exact departure platform, delays, cancellations etc. Do not base yourself on your destination cause it may not be the final destination of the train’s journey.

Some stations are huge with long or far away platforms, make sure you get to your platform at least 10 mins before set time. Sometimes platforms aren’t announced until very last minutes, stay close to access points so you can hurry to your platform once it’s displayed.

Make sure to double check coach and seat number before boarding to avoid walking the whole train and creating traffic onboard.

Secure luggage on overhead racks if possible above your seat; or store your luggage in between seats in front of you so you can have them visible at all times.

Head to the doors a few minutes before leaving the train especially if your destination is not the final stop.

You can follow the route through the Infomobilità section on the Trenitalia app Italo app or Google map to see the train stops. Normally stops are announced but you may miss it if it’s dark, noisy etc.

Main train companies are Trenitalia (state owned) and Italo. Trenitalia operates both local and fast trains whereas Italo operates only fast trains.

The main connecting train stations are:

Roma Termini
Milano Centrale
Bologna Centrale
Firenze Santa Maria Novella (SMN)
Napoli Centrale
Venezia Santa Lucia (S. L.)

These stations all have fast trains connecting them via Italo or Trenitalia. Some parts of Italy do not have fast trains (especially coastal areas and some southern parts of the country.)

Always look for the CAPOTRENO for any info while on the train. In the stations go to info points operated by Trenitalia or if travelling with Italo, find their info points.

Ticketing machines for Trenitalia and Italo are different. Not all stations have operating ticket offices (only a handful in bigger train stations) so beware.

Hope this helps.

text:
We arrived home. Must say waking up in the middle of the night in your own house is confusing after being away for three weeks and staying in eight different places.

I have received many requests for full details of our trip and once I get caught up on work stuff I will put a post together. But as I know people are actively planning their own trips will share some details of our itinerary and accommodation happy to answer any questions as this group was a great resource for my planning.

Days 1-4: Florence in large three bedroom apartment (can be booked as AirBnB but I booked with Apartments Florence), tons of stairs but the location by Mercato Centrale and the two rooftop decks made it worth it.

Van with driver from Florence to Vernazza with stops in Siena (1 hr), San Gimignano (2 hrs - grabbed lunch) and Pisa (1 hr) was well worth the money. Our driver was great like having someone uncle or poppi drive you around.

Days 4-7: Stayed in Vernazza which after visiting all five towns in Cinque Terre was 100% our favourite. We explored all towns by foot and train. We LOVED Carattino 12 where we stayed that we have booked with Cinque Terre Vacation. Ruth was by far the most amazing host I have ever dealt with and the apartment was amazing. On our final night there booked a five hour sunset cruise with hellocinqueterre which was the highlight of our weekend there. They are based out of Manarola and were amazing. Seeing the towns from the water was amazing and you could even arrange to visit a few or stop for swimming if your time allows.

Train from Vernazza to La Specia and connecting train to Rome.

Days 7-11: Rome (yes this was a lot of time but we knew it was going to be the hottest part of our trip and we were planning on going back to our apartment in the afternoon every day which we did). As we were there for more days we were not rushed at all which was great as it game us a chance to relax and enjoy the city and all it had to offer. We stayed in a massive four bedroom apartment that was located in Ponte which we thought was a great location.

Caught train from Rome to Naples and changed to the Campania Express to continue our travel to Sorrento (the journey on the Campania Express was one of the only crappy parts of our entire trip, wish we had just booked a van)

Days 11-13: Sorrento we booked Raffaele’s place through AirBnB. Was a strange place in the end as it was four bedroom units with ensuites off of a main corridor. Would be great for couples or people traveling together that want their own space but for a family was weird. It was centrally located and clean. The area was a bit loud at night but got the sense that a lot of Sorrento is loud at night on a weekend. Fun town though. On the Sunday (day 12) we were picked up by a driver to head back up to Pompeii and Herculaneum for a private tour that I had arranged. The guide Ludovica from Ludviguida was just amazing, we had originally found her though Tours with Locals but easier to book her directly through her Instagram or website. Driver took us back to Sorrento after the tours.

Days 13-16: Capri and Amalfi Coast we were on Capasecca for this time and it was amazing and super memorable. Pretty big splurge but do not regret it for one second. Being on a boat avoided traffic and allowed us to be in Capri and Amalfi after the day trippers had left which is a completely different experience. The girls all loved Capri so next time we will likely stay there for a few nights and arrange day trips by chartering a boat to visit other towns if we want.

Days 16-17: Booked van with driver drive us to Naples for the night. Had just planned on late dinner and sleeping there but aftr having met Ludovica we arranged last minute to have a tour of her beloved home city Naples the morning before we left. We did a two hour tour with her and only wish we had had more time but will be back.

Train from Naples to Bologna and then out to Parma.

Days 17-19: Parma we just stayed at the Novotel as there were very limited options when we booked as it was late change to our itinerary to go to the Harry Styles final concert of his world tour. The hotel staff was great, hotel was clean and we got one of the few adjoining rooms which made us happy (when were were told the room numbers were 322 and 329 by front desk we were not expecting them to be adjoining). We didn’t really get a chance to explore the town or area but did squeeze in a tour of a cheese factory which was fun and cool to see.

Days 19-20: Train back to Florence via Bologna. This was the only missed train connection of our trip. Had booked a hotel for our final night just because meeting someone for keys for one night seemed like dumb idea. In the end it was the most amazing finally night we could have hoped for with an absurd room upgrade. The hotel had a small outdoor pool in a garden setting and staff were great. We will definitely stay that next time we are in Florence.
